### More Problems for Fortinet: Critical FortiSIEM Flaw Exploited


üìä **TECH INSIGHT**


In a recent cybersecurity development, Fortinet, a prominent provider of cybersecurity solutions, faces a critical challenge as a severe flaw in its FortiSIEM security information and event management (SIEM) system was actively exploited by malicious actors. This vulnerability, identified as CVE-2023-284, allows unauthenticated attackers to execute arbitrary code on affected systems, posing significant risks to organizations using the FortiSIEM product. As a result, Fortinet has urged its customers to immediately apply available

### Predator Spyware Sample Indicates 'Vendor-Controlled' C2


üìä **TECH INSIGHT**


The article discusses new findings regarding Predator spyware, particularly focusing on its command-and-control (C2) infrastructure, which appears to be "vendor-controlled." This suggests a sophisticated operational structure where the vendor retains significant influence over the spyware's deployment and functionality. The analysis of a Predator sample highlights that this centralized control could potentially allow the vendor to dictate or influence the spyware's targets and activities. Such a setup raises concerns about the implications for operational security and the potential misuse of the spyware by various actors. The

**[Read the full article ‚Ä∫](https://www.darkreading.com/mobile-security/predator-spyware-sample-vendor-controlled-c2?utm_source=newsletter&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=weekly_ai_cybersecurity&utm_content=article_352)**

### Black Basta boss makes it onto Interpol's 'Red Notice' list


üìä **TECH INSIGHT**


Interpol has issued a "Red Notice" for an alleged leader of the Black Basta ransomware group, marking a significant development in international efforts to combat cybercrime. The individual in question is believed to be a key figure in orchestrating a series of high-profile ransomware attacks on businesses and institutions worldwide. This "Red Notice" allows for heightened international cooperation in tracking and potentially apprehending the suspect, as it flags the individual as wanted by law enforcement in all Interpol member countries. This move underscores the growing global

**[Read the full article ‚Ä∫](https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/black-basta-boss-makes-it-onto-interpols-red-notice-list/?utm_source=newsletter&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=weekly_ai_cybersecurity&utm_content=article_4973)**

### Microsoft Patch Tuesday for January 2026 ‚Äî Snort rules and prominent vulnerabilities


üìä **TECH INSIGHT**


In the January 2026 edition of Microsoft's Patch Tuesday, several critical vulnerabilities were addressed to enhance system security across various products. This monthly update focused on mitigating risks associated with multiple zero-day exploits, which could potentially allow attackers to compromise systems. Notably, key vulnerabilities were identified in products like Windows OS and Microsoft Exchange Server, necessitating immediate attention and patch application by users to prevent potential breaches. Alongside these updates, Cisco's Snort team released new rules to detect and block attempts to exploit these

**[Read the full article ‚Ä∫](https://blog.talosintelligence.com/microsoft-patch-tuesday-january-2026/?utm_source=newsletter&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=weekly_ai_cybersecurity&utm_content=article_7919)**

### Remote Code Execution With Modern AI/ML Formats and Libraries


üß† **AI ADVANCEMENT**


The article "Remote Code Execution With Modern AI/ML Formats and Libraries" discusses the potential security vulnerabilities in AI and machine learning models when using modern data formats and libraries. It highlights how attackers can exploit these vulnerabilities to achieve remote code execution, allowing them to execute arbitrary code on a target system. The article underscores the importance of understanding these risks and implementing robust security measures in AI/ML development workflows. It also examines common libraries and formats, offering insights into how developers can safeguard their applications against such attacks

**[Read the full article ‚Ä∫](https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/rce-vulnerabilities-in-ai-python-libraries/?utm_source=newsletter&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=weekly_ai_cybersecurity&utm_content=article_8840)**
